title: Prohibits restaurants in certain cities from serving water except upon request
summary: Prohibits restaurants in cities with a population of one million or more from serving drinking water from a tap to patrons, except upon request of patrons; defines relevant terms; excludes catering and banquet facilities.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2125

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to serving water to
patrons in restaurants in certain cities

PURPOSE:
This bill directs that restaurants in cities of a population of a
million or more shall be prohibited from serving water except upon
request.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 of this bill states the legislative intent. The
legislature recognizes that drinking water is an essential resource
and it should be conserved whenever possible. This legislation
encourages consumers and commercial establishments to conserve water.

Section 2 amends the general business law by adding a new section
399-bb. This section stipulates that any restaurant in a city with a
population of a million or more shall be prohibited to serve drinking
water to any patron unless requested by the patron. For the first
violation, the court shall issue a warning. A civil penalty of not
more than $500 shall be issued for the second violation and not more
than $1,000 for the third and subsequent violations. The term
"restaurant" applies to coffee shops, cafeterias, luncheonettes,
diners, short order cafes, fast food establishments, and eateries.
Catering and banquet halls shall be exempt from the provisions of
this bill.

Section 3 is the enacting clause. This act shall take effect on the
sixtieth day after it shall become law.

JUSTIFICATION:
This bill recognizes the importance of water conservancy and
encourages commercial establishments and consumers to conserve water
wherever and whenever possible. Even in these times of plenty, water
should be conserved in the event that clean drinking water should
become a scarce resource. Too often water is unnecessarily wasted.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the sixtieth day
after it shall become law.
